numeric_premises.content: The severity of a differential diagnosis is rarely severe or moderate, specifically a 90% chance of no severity and a 5% chance of mild severity, while severe and moderate diagnoses are quite unlikely with only 2% and 3% chances, respectively.

A mixed type of differential diagnosis is overwhelmingly likely with a 93.5% probability, while a motor type diagnosis has a 6% chance, and sensory neuron involvement is highly unlikely with a 0.5% probability.

If the differential diagnosis is motor neuron related and shows no severity, then the sensory neuron involvement in the differential diagnosis is certainly nonexistent, whereas mild, moderate or severe involvement is not possible.
Given a mixed differential diagnosis with no severity, the sensory neuron involvement in the differential diagnosis is guaranteed to be of no severity, carrying a 100% probability.
In the case of a sensory differential diagnosis with no severity, the sensory neuron involvement in the differential diagnosis is definitely nonexistent, with a 100% probability.
If the differential diagnosis is related to motor neurons and has a mild severity, then the sensory neuron involvement in the differential diagnosis is certainly not present, with a 100% probability.
When the differential diagnosis is mixed and has a mild severity, the sensory neuron involvement in the differential diagnosis is definitely mild, carrying a 100% probability.
If the differential diagnosis is sensory and has a mild severity, then the sensory neuron involvement in the differential diagnosis is definitely mild, carrying a 100% probability.
In the case of a motor differential diagnosis with a moderate severity, the sensory neuron involvement in the differential diagnosis is guaranteed to be nonexistent, with a 100% probability.
When the differential diagnosis is mixed and has a moderate severity, the sensory neuron involvement in the differential diagnosis is definitely moderate, carrying a 100% probability.
If the differential diagnosis is sensory and has a moderate severity, then the sensory neuron involvement in the differential diagnosis is definitely moderate, carrying a 100% probability.
In the case of a motor differential diagnosis with a severe severity, the sensory neuron involvement in the differential diagnosis is guaranteed to be nonexistent, with a 100% probability.
When the differential diagnosis is mixed and has a severe severity, the sensory neuron involvement in the differential diagnosis is definitely severe, carrying a 100% probability.
If the differential diagnosis is sensory and has a severe severity, then the sensory neuron involvement in the differential diagnosis is definitely severe, carrying a 100% probability.

In the context of differential diagnosis, it is highly unlikely that the type is motor, almost certain that the type is mixed, and there is almost no chance that the type is sensory.
